subject: Re: [junit] Promlem in writing Test case
msgSnippet: Hi Joakim Your suggestion was very helpful to me. I was missing the base line while testing. I was trying to test and compare the code with something which was
messageBody:
Hi Joakim
Your suggestion was very helpful to me. I was missing the base line while testing. I was trying to test and compare the code with something which was not known to me. May be I was trying to hit the problem in a black box way. I have gone through your sample code snippets send to me and I will try to break the code in such a way so that I can test it by comparing to some known values. That will I guess provide me with better stats !!

Thanks a Lot for your kind help

-Avinash


----- Original Message ----
From: Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...>
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, 14 November, 2006 6:01:36 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] Promlem in writing Test case

To me it sounds like the first thing you need to do is take control of your
environment from your tests.
From what you wrote below maybe I would do something like this:

public TestVersionCalculat or extends TestCase {

public testCalculatorVersi onIsNewer_ ReturnsZero( ) {
VersionCalculator calculator = new VersionCalculator( "7.1.1");
AssertEquals( "0", calculator.calculat e("7.0.1" ));
}

public testCalculatorVersi onOlder_ReturnsN ewest() {
VersionCalculator calculator = new VersionCalculator( "6.1.5");
AssertEquals( ""7.1.0"" , calculator.calculat e("7.1.0" ));
}
}

When that works I would maybe write a test for something that can read the
XML so that if the XML contains a specific version I know that particular
version would be returned:

public void TestXmlVersionReade r extends TestCase {
public testReadsVersionFro mReader() {
Reader xmlInput = new StringReader( "<?xml version='1.0' '><version>
7.0.1</version> ") ;
VersionReader versionReader = new XmlVersionReader( xmlInput) ;
AssertEquals( "7.0.1", versionReader. readVersion( ));
}

public testReadsVersionFro mReader() {
Reader xmlInput = new StringReader( "<?xml version='1.0' '><version>
6.0.5</version> ") ;
VersionReader versionReader = new XmlVersionReader( xmlInput) ;
AssertEquals( "6.0.5", versionReader. readVersion( ));
}
}

When that works you have something that can read a version from your xml and
something that can calculate a version.
Now I would maybe revisit the first test again:

public TestVersionCalculat or extends TestCase {

public testCalculatorVersi onIsNewer_ ReturnsZero( ) {
VersionCalculator calculator = new VersionCalculator( "7.1.1",

new VersionReader( ) {

public String readVersion( ) {

return "7.0.1";

}

});
AssertEquals( "0", calculator.calculat e());
}

public testCalculatorVersi onOlder_ReturnsN ewest() {
VersionCalculator calculator = new VersionCalculator( "6.1.5",

new VersionReader( ) {

public String readVersion( ) {

return "7.1.0";

}

});
AssertEquals( ""7.1.0"" , calculator.calculat e());
}
}

That is just a simple example, where you start and the order things are
implemented is unimportant. The important thing is to identify
responsibilities and test them so that you are sure that they work. Some
prefer to test larger chunks at the time, attack the problem from a
different direction and so on, that is ok too. The bottom line is that you
have to have a /known/ in your test. You have to know what the conditions
are and how your system should behave with those conditions. Otherwise the
test will have to run the same code as the code that is tested which, as you
say, provides no value.

I think you do know what to expect, there must be some rule, after all you
knew how to write the code. I think the problem you are facing is that you
maybe want to run the tests in an environment that you don't control. Why do
you want to do that? What is the gain?.
If you take control of your environment the testing is simple and consists
of figuring out how to force your system into situations in which you can be
sure how it should respond and have enough of those situations so you can be
sure that your system works. The real gain is when you can write those tests
as you develop the code and be able to listen to your tests so that they can
contribute back to your design.

Does that make sense or am I completely missing something about what you are
trying to do?

On 11/14/06, avinash anand <avinash_anand@ yahoo.co. uk> wrote:
>
> Hi Shane
> This here is something different. I want to testh this code in a dynamic
> enviroment, meaning the system will be feed with different xml files using
> diffrent permutation and combination. For instance if the current version
> installed is 7.1.1 and the xml file feed has a version 7.0.1 the code will
> return 0, if the current version is 6.1.5 and the xml file reads 7.1.0 the
> code will return 7.1.0 Hence I will never be sure of the expected result.
>
> Is there any other way to test the code sent earlier,
>
> 1. In term of usability
> 2. In term of testing exception
> 3. In term of results
>
> Thanks
> Aviansh
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: Shane Mingins <shane.mingins@ gmail.com <shane.mingins% 40gmail.com> >
> To: junit@yahoogroups. com <junit%40yahoogroup s.com>
> Sent: Tuesday, 14 November, 2006 1:50:06 PM
> Subject: Re: [junit] Promlem in writing Test case
>
> On 11/14/06, avinash anand <avinash_anand@ yahoo.co. uk> wrote:
> > Hi All
> > I am writing a test case in JUnit. The original class GetInfo.java has a
> method. String getSystemVersion( String str) which is under test. This
> method is supplied with path variable in form of string from where it reads
> a xml file to get certain data and return back to the user.
> >
> > The point of confussion for me is to how to test the method. What should
> be the actual and expected result. Meaning for getting the expected result I
> will have to use the same logic as it is in the main code, if I use the same
> logic to read the xml file then the assert statement would not be meaningful
> as then the expected and actual results would be same.
>
> I am not sure why you have to use the same logic to calculate the
> expected result?
>
> You have an xml file that u will use for the test (I personally might
> do something different) in which you know what version you expect back
> ... so you code assert_equals( 0,
> getinfo.getSystemVe rsion(fileToRetu rnZero)) etc.
>
> cheers
> shane
>
